rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today‚Äôs lesson is about helping children follow rules and instructions by using consequences.

Consequences are the good or negative things that happen after a child‚Äôs actions. When children don‚Äôt follow a rule, giving consequences can help them learn and take responsibility for their actions.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today‚Äôs lesson is about helping children follow rules and instructions by using consequences.

Consequences are the good or negative things that happen after a child‚Äôs actions. When children don‚Äôt follow a rule, giving consequences can help them learn and take responsibility for their actions.

media_title.eng: How can calm consequences help you and your family?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings everyone.

Even if you do everything right, your child will misbehave sometimes. We may be tempted to scream and shout, but that just leaves everyone more angry. 

If we stay calm, and give them a calm consequence, they will learn to take responsibility for their actions instead.

rows.media_title: How can calm consequences help you and your family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings everyone.

Even if you do everything right, your child will misbehave sometimes. We may be tempted to scream and shout, but that just leaves everyone more angry. 

If we stay calm, and give them a calm consequence, they will learn to take responsibility for their actions instead.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Some consequences happen naturally ‚Äì like when a toy breaks, it can‚Äôt be used.

Others are set by you to help your child follow rules (_‚Äúif you don‚Äôt pack away your toys, you can‚Äôt play with them tomorrow‚Äù_). 

Let‚Äôs see how @data.characters.f1_father.name uses consequences to help his son, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name, follow instructions:

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Some consequences happen naturally ‚Äì like when a toy breaks, it can‚Äôt be used.

Others are set by you to help your child follow rules (_‚Äúif you don‚Äôt pack away your toys, you can‚Äôt play with them tomorrow‚Äù_). 

Let‚Äôs see how @data.characters.f1_father.name uses consequences to help his son, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name, follow instructions:

character_1_text.eng: You are playing so nice and quiet, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to clean up your toys.

rows.character_1_text: You are playing so nice and quiet, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to clean up your toys.

character_1_text.eng: It‚Äôs time to put away your toys.

rows.character_1_text: It‚Äôs time to put away your toys.
@data.characters.f1_son_5.name, either you put away the toys now, or you won‚Äôt be able to play with your toys after dinner.

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f1_son_5.name, either you put away the toys now, or you won‚Äôt be able to play with your toys after dinner.

character_2_text.eng: No, @data.characters.f1_father.role_name! I don‚Äôt want to! I‚Äôm not finished with my game.

rows.character_2_text: No, @data.characters.f1_father.role_name! I don‚Äôt want to! I‚Äôm not finished with my game.

rows.character_1_text:
Because you did not clean up your toys when I asked you to, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name, you cannot play with your toys after dinner. 
Now please come and wash your hands.

character_1_text.eng:
Because you did not clean up your toys when I asked you to, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name, you cannot play with your toys after dinner. 
Now please come and wash your hands.

rows.character_1_text: You are washing your hands so nicely, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name ‚Äì well done!

character_1_text.eng: You are washing your hands so nicely, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name ‚Äì well done!

rows.text_1_facilitator: @data.characters.f1_father.name used a consequence to help @data.characters.f1_son_5.name learn that actions have impacts.

text_1_facilitator.eng: @data.characters.f1_father.name used a consequence to help @data.characters.f1_son_5.name learn that actions have impacts.

text_2.eng:
@data.characters.f1_father.name did this by:
- üòå Staying calm 
- ü§ùüèæ Involving @data.characters.f1_son_5.name in planning the consequence 
- üíú Giving a fair consequence related to the behaviour (no playing after dinner if you don't put toys away) 
- ‚≠ê Being consistent by following through with the consequence

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Try again! @data.characters.f1_father.name explains the consequence in a calm way.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: He speaks calmly and explains why he is giving the consequence

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
That‚Äôs right. @data.characters.f1_father.name shows us that it‚Äôs important to introduce consequences when you are feeling calm and makes sure that @data.characters.f1_son_5.name understands why he can‚Äôt play after dinner. 
There are two right answers! Did you find them?

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: He gets a bit angry, but then makes the consequence clear

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng:
That‚Äôs right. @data.characters.f1_father.name shows us that it‚Äôs important to follow through for the consequence to work. 
There are two right answers! Did you find them?

quiz_2_question.eng:
What would @data.characters.f1_son_5.name learn if @data.characters.f1_father.name gives in or does not give the consequence? 

@data.characters.f1_son_5.name would learn:

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: He can get away with this behaviour in the future

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Exactly. It is really important to follow through with what we say, so our children learn boundaries and know they can trust our word.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: Not to listen when his @data.characters.f1_father.role_name gives instructions

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Exactly. It is really important to follow through with what we say, so our children learn boundaries and know they can trust our word.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: That @data.characters.f1_father.name loves him and forgives him

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Try again! @data.characters.f1_son_5.name would actually learn not to take @data.characters.f1_father.name seriously when he gives an instruction, or that he can get away with this behaviour in the future.

- ‚≠ê Being consistent by following through with the consequence

rows.quiz_2_option_1_text: He can get away with this behaviour in the future
rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: Exactly. It is really important to follow through with what we say, so our children learn boundaries and know they can trust our word.

rows.quiz_2_feedback_3: Try again! @data.characters.f1_son_5.name would actually learn not to take @data.characters.f1_father.name seriously when he gives an instruction, or that he can get away with this behaviour in the future.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are some easy steps to use consequences when your child does not listen.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some easy steps to use consequences when your child does not listen.

section_1_text.eng:
Take some deep breaths or walk away from the situation if you need to.

Then, respond in a calm, clear way.

section_1_extra_text.eng: Shouting at our children only makes things worse. It also teaches them that it is okay to treat others like this when they are upset.

section_2_text.eng: Give a consequence connected to the behaviour, and make sure it is something you can follow through with.

section_2_extra_text.eng:
For example, if they do not clean up their toys, they cannot play with them the next day (rather than the whole week).

If your child is experiencing a natural consequence for their action (like not being able to play with their toy after breaking it), you might not need to give them an additional consequence.

section_3_text.eng: Follow through with a consequence every time a rule is broken, even if it feels small. Being consistent shows your child you mean what you say and helps them take the rules seriously.

section_3_extra_text.eng: If you miss a chance to follow through, do not worry ‚Äì just try again next time.

section_4_text.eng: Ask your child what a fair consequence might be if a rule is not followed. This helps them learn responsibility and makes it more likely they will stick to the rule.

section_4_extra_text.eng: You can also involve your child in choosing simple and free rewards for their behaviours. This will encourage them to follow the rules more often!

rows.section_1_text:
Take some deep breaths or walk away from the situation if you need to.

Then, respond in a calm, clear way.
rows.section_1_extra_text: Shouting at our children only makes things worse. It also teaches them that it is okay to treat others like this when they are upset.
rows.section_2_text: Give a consequence connected to the behaviour, and make sure it is something you can follow through with.
rows.section_2_extra_text:
For example, if they do not clean up their toys, they cannot play with them the next day (rather than the whole week).

If your child is experiencing a natural consequence for their action (like not being able to play with their toy after breaking it), you might not need to give them an additional consequence.
rows.section_3_text: Follow through with a consequence every time a rule is broken, even if it feels small. Being consistent shows your child you mean what you say and helps them take the rules seriously.
rows.section_3_extra_text: If you miss a chance to follow through, do not worry ‚Äì just try again next time.
rows.section_4_text: Ask your child what a fair consequence might be if a rule is not followed. This helps them learn responsibility and makes it more likely they will stick to the rule.
rows.section_4_extra_text: You can also involve your child in choosing simple and free rewards for their behaviours. This will encourage them to follow the rules more often!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Now that we have learned a few useful tips, let‚Äôs come up with some ideas for reasonable and realistic consequences.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Now that we have learned a few useful tips, let‚Äôs come up with some ideas for reasonable and realistic consequences.

quiz_1_question.eng: Would any of these consequences be helpful for you and your child?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: If you are late for dinner, your food will be cold

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: If you continue splashing water out of the bath, bath time will be over

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: If you break your toy, you will have no toy to play with

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: If you can‚Äôt play close to home where I can see you, then you have to come inside

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_5_text.eng: If you do not put away your toys, then you cannot play with them tomorrow morning

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out tomorrow.

quiz_1_option_6_text.eng: None of these will work in my home

quiz_1_feedback_6.eng: That's okay! Try to think of just one consequence that you feel confident you can follow-through with in a calm way. Try starting with something small.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Your home activity is to discuss one household rule that your child finds hard to follow and agree on a fair consequence together. 

Remember, if you praise your child when they follow rules, you will see more positive behaviour in your home.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Your home activity is to discuss one household rule that your child finds hard to follow and agree on a fair consequence together. 

Remember, if you praise your child when they follow rules, you will see more positive behaviour in your home.

media_title.eng: Agreeing on consequences together works! Tap play to hear @data.characters.media_female_13.name's story

quiz_1_question.eng: The next time your child does not follow a rule, can you use a fair consequence in a calm way?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! Remember to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm, and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's great! Remember to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm, and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. Keep trying. It will get easier in time. You can start by considering smaller behaviours that your child struggles with and planning a fair consequence in advance so you're ready.
